name: Electrical Power
description: You will have to use electrically-powered equipment to build some of the components for your moon rocket. Well, they aren't technically powered electrically. They're powered by a system known as "Redstone Flux." Some other mods have their own systems, but they are all compatible with this. It's quite close to an idea of electrical power, with generators sending power through ducts/cables to devices. Here you can see some of the options, including a nuclear reactor (not as scary as it sounds).

quests.name: Steel My Thunder
quests.description: Time for some steel! There are two machines that can do this: the induction smelter, and the metallurgic infuser. The induction smelter works with 4 charcoal dust or 2 coal dust to one iron ingot. Make sure to unlock the flux slot, which is that goofy triangle-thing button. The metallurgic infuser takes two coal or charcoal per iron ingot. You run the iron ingot through once to enrich it, and then run it through again to make steel dust. You can cook that into a steel ingot.

tasks.longDescription: The infuser is cheaper to make, but you theoretically can be more efficient with coal dust in the induction smelter.

quests.name: I Induce You Need Steel
quests.description: The induction smelter can kinda-sorta more than double yield on specific materials. If fed sand and an ore, it will automatically double it. It will sometimes spit out flux. If you smelt with that instead of sand, you will triple your yield. However, it's main perk in this mod pack is that it can make steel ingots. The recipe is either 4 charcoal dust or 2 coal dust per iron ingot. To make that dust, you'll have to pulverize coal or charcoal. For that, you need a pulverizer. You might already have one!

tasks.longDescription: Create the basic versions of the pulverizer and the induction smelter.

quests.name: Power Starts With Redstone
quests.description: Redstone is a material mined in the original Minecraft. There, it's used like a signal for basic logic. If you heard somebody simulate a processor in Minecraft, it was with redstone. In Minecraft mods, redstone is very often used for power generation. The technical mods tend to use a power system to operate their machines. Most have settled on a power system known as "redstone flux" or RF. So let's start generating RF!

tasks.longDescription: Redstone is fairly common once you dig deep enough. In the Nether, it's actually more at and above the center height of Y=64. So if you go to the Nether, dig up, not down.

quests.name: The Survivalist's Generator
quests.description: This little generator is extremely fuel-efficient, but outputs power SLOOOWLY. You could fix that by... making a ton of them. However, if you make a giant tower out of them, I might find you, and mock it. You have been warned. This is still a great way to get started.

tasks.longDescription: Okay, you make one, I'll give you one. I recommend feeding it wood planks.

quests.name: Your Basic Power Cable
quests.description: There are various connectors, but we will focus on the ones in Thermal Dynamics, a bulwark for power delivery pipes. The basic power cable there is the leadstone fluxduct. It's fairly simple to make. However, it cannot transmit too much power. You can attach it to multiple sides and create alternate routes to get around this . . . for a while.

quests.name: Graphite . . . For Nukes!
quests.description: So you have a problem. You decide, "I will build a nuclear reactor." Now you have . . . lots of problems. This reactor can't explode on you, contaminate the world, and kill you constantly. It just requires a lot of stuff to make. It will take over a hundred graphite, made from 1 charcoal/coal each, and over a hundred yellorium ingots. For your trouble, you will build a 5x5x5 structure that will provide WAAAAY more power than you need for the moon trip. You can reduce the burn rate, or just build crazier stuff to use up all the RF.

tasks.longDescription: Burn wood into charcoal, and then charcoal into graphite. Repeat lots of times. You can use coal too, but that's a nice thing to keep around for making steel. Note, consider automating this step and making tons of graphite. For one, you can line the reactor with graphite blocks to boost performance. This could double its performance. For another, turbine components also need graphite . . . when we get there.

quests.name: Lava Power
quests.description: This generator runs on lava. No joke. Right click it with a bucket of lava and it will take it into its tank and start to hum on it. It's possible to get your rocket put together with just this power alone.

quests.name: Big People Solar
quests.description: If you get 4 of the basic solar generators, you can combine them into the advanced generator. It will generate 1.5x the power of the original 4 cells.

quests.name: Burning Food For Science
quests.description: The culinary generator . . . burns food to produce RF. It's not that bad really if you have an automatic farm set up. It's just kind of silly.

quests.name: I'm Your Biggest Fan
quests.description: This is a turnkey, sustainable, fire-and-forget power generator. So long as the turbine can see the sky overhead and has plenty of room around it. It also generates more power the higher up in the world it is. If you built on top of a mountain, this should work pretty well for you.

tasks.longDescription: Side-note: Solar panels and wind turbines are considered "passive generation." Some mods have these, and they usually have low generation rates. Resist the urge to build tons of these to compensate. If you play on a server, the server will choke, and everybody will make fun of you. Switch to the tougher, more powerful, active generators. They are more interesting to work with anyways.

quests.name: A Hardcore Fluxduct
quests.description: The hardened fluxduct can transmit 4x the RF power of a leadstone fluxduct. You make it by augmenting existing leadstone fluxduct with invar. Invar is a 2:1 alloy of iron:nickel. You may find nickel in the world as ferrous ore. It's pretty rare. These ducts are more than you need to get to the moon . . . unless you make that nuclear reactor and maybe that digital miner.

quests.name: Weak Solar Power
quests.description: Solar power is sustainable, turnkey, and fire-and-forget . . . except that it stops at night. You will need an energy cell to store power for the night. You will also need some Mekanism equipment to make these. However, if you make that gear, you're part of the way to the Digital Miner in the Post-Scarcity section. Think about it.

tasks.longDescription: One of these will provide 40RF/tick, which is better than the survivalist generator, but only during the day! Given a 24-hour cycle, the solar generator is only marginally better, but at least you don't have to constantly feed it wood.

quests.name: Baby's First Battery
quests.description: The leadstone energy cell is a starter battery. All the power generators maintain a power reserve, but that might not be enough. This is especially an issue if you are using solar power. You need to buffer it overnight! Even if you don't, an energy cell can discharge much more quickly than some generators, and are good for jobs on the pinch. The fact that they're portable is quite useful too. USE A CRESCENT HAMMER TO MOVE THEM!

tasks.longDescription: ***NOTE*** Ender IO capacitor banks have generally taken the place of these energy cells. They do a lot of it better and cheaper.

quests.name: Yellowcake, yellowcake . . .
quests.description: Remember the 64 ingots I gave you for the graphite? That won't be enough! You will need more just to build the reactor. It will need fuel. So I will be asking for 64 yellorium ingots.

tasks.longDescription: Do not use your furnace or smeltery for this! The yield is terrible! Consider pulverizing or crushing the ore first, then running it through a furnace. You can also use Artifice uranium ore generally, but I cannot set up the quest book to detect one or the other, so yellorium it is! You should be able to normally find that ore in any modpack that includes Big Reactors.

quests.name: The Power Of The Atom
quests.description: Let's start putting all this together. You will need reactor blocks first. You will then use some of them to make a controller, an access port, a power tap, and a control rod. You will then need 3 fuel rods. Build a 5x5 floor out of the reactor blocks. Place the 3 fuel rods as a tower in the center. Encase it on all sides, except for placing the port, tap, and controller somewhere accessible from the outside--but not the corners. Close it off with the remaining cases. Put yellorium in the access port, and try to activate the reactor from the controller. It will tell you if it doesn't like something, and exactly where the thing it doesn't like is or isn't. Good luck!

tasks.longDescription: If I did the math right, this should be all the blocks you need for a 5x5x5 reactor, including what is consumed in making the controller, access port, and power tap. Previous editions of this book recommended filling the reactor with water. DO NOT DO THIS. You can improve this reactor if you fill it up with blocks of graphite, or dump buckets of destabilized redstone into the top of it.

quests.name: Cooking With RF
quests.description: The RF furnace is a no-frills furnace replacement. Well, one perk it has is that can cook food especially fast compared to the other heating machines, if you are into that kind of thing.

tasks.longDescription: Let's start with what you need for the basic frame, a tin gear.
The basic machine frame needs that tin gear and some basic materials like iron and glass.
Now the furnace.

quests.name: I Pulverize Your Head!
quests.description: Here is another grinding machine that has a chance of side-products. When you see pulverizer recipes in NEI, this is what it is talking about. You can get basic ore-doubling with this and the RF-furnace, which isn't really the best. One thing that sets the pulverizer apart from the other machines is how consistently it grinds cobblestone into sand. This can help with making glass.

tasks.longDescription: Get used to tin gears when it comes to Thermal Expansion.
Get used to these machine frames too.

quests.name: Three Times The Alloy
quests.description: Well hey, another RF-powered furnace! This one is from Ender IO. One big claim to fame for it is it can burn down three things at once. It is pretty intense on the iron, but if that is cheap for you, you should consider it over the others. You will also need this if you want to make other Ender IO stuff like their conduits.

tasks.longDescription: Get used to these capacitors. They are a regular Ender IO component. They take a little gold, a copper ingot, and redstone. This is the most exotic component.
It's time to start feeding this thing lots of iron. The chasis is a common item for the Ender IO machines in general.
Since it can burn through three things at once, it does make sense it wants three furnaces. The rest comes to the previous steps, and a bunch of iron.

quests.name: Rolling In Balls
quests.description: In real life, SAG stands for "semi-autogenous grinding." It's a tub full of ball bearings that are spin. They pound away on your product. The EnderIO one uses flint. You can grind without extra flint, but feeding some in will potentially increase your yield. For example, an iron ore without flint will give you two dusts, which give you two ingots. However, a SAG mill with flint fed into the right-hand slot will sometimes quadruple that. Statistically, it will boost your base yield by 2.5x, and that's better than the smeltery.

tasks.longDescription: Pro tip: You can use the Mekanism crusher to turn cobblestone into gravel. From there, the SAG mill can process the gravel into flint. If you run the flint through a crusher again, you'll get gunpowder. Hint, hint . . .

quests.name: Smelting Your Face Off
quests.description: Yeap, another furnace. It kind of stinks as-is, but this machine can go through a fairly straightforward set of upgrades to be ridiculously fast and efficient, using the same upgrades that will go into the digital miner. If you are heading for that, you should soon have the tooling to make this too. I generally just use an energized smelter when setting up *triple ore processing* since it works well with the other Mekanism machines.

tasks.longDescription: The obnoxious thing is you need steel to make an otherwise straightforward machine.
Yeah, it needs osmium and you help from a metallurgic infuser to make the circuit boards.

quests.name: I Crush Your Ores!
quests.description: Continuing the theme of Mekanism machines sounding like stuff from a Nine Inch Nails video, the crusher sounds like it is brutally executing your ores and objects. You will need one crusher for the digital miner quest line eventually due to very peculiar outputs from this machine for doing Mekanism stuff. Side Note: This also repeats a digital miner quest in the post-scarcity chapter. Feel good about it!

tasks.longDescription: I'd like to highlight that a crusher turns cobblestone into gravel. A SAG mill can turn gravel into flint, and you can turn around to another crusher and turn the flint into gunpowder . . . hint, hint.

quests.name: Love Machines
quests.description: Now you can do the basic machines! Unfortunately, we have three packs that do the starter machines. The typical thing is to get some kind of heating machine, and some kind of grinding machine. One replaces your coal-fired furnace, and the other processes items to break them down. They usually get you some ore multiplication bonus. The bonuses can vary, so you want to see what you need and then determine which way to go. Ender IO machines tend to be high in iron. Thermal Expansion machines will eat on the copper. Mekanism will require steel and osmium. They all have their perks.

tasks.longDescription: Across the machines, you will at least need some glass, copper, gold, and glass.

quests.name: All Along The Boomtower
quests.description: Advanced Quest! You can combine the processing machines into something that gives you all the ingredients to make TNT. You can then feed the TNT into the TNT generator! This will shoot out random explosions all over the place. I normally stuff them up on a tower. It's mostly just for giggles. If you're a kid, you should make sure your speakers are plugged in when you're running this so you can show your annoyed parents how awesome you are!

tasks.longDescription: Make a TNT generator. Just one. You know, to get started. It needs some TNT in the recipe. The big deal here is the gunpowder. Crush (crusher) cobblestone to make gravel, and then pulverize (pulverizer) the gravel to get flint, and then crush (crusher again) that to get gunpowder.

quests.name: Cyanora
quests.description: Cyanite is the waste product of a Big Reactor. You want to check your fuel ports for an accumulation of them, because your reactor's efficiency will steadily drop as converts all the fuel. That being said, this is good stuff! You can reprocess it to get a little more fuel, or use it as a base material in turbines.

tasks.longDescription: Hey, I don't care how you get it. Either pull some out of your reactor, or mix some yellorium with sand, and you'll have some cyanite to play with. I'm going to give you some more to make a turbine!

quests.name: Turning The Blues Around
quests.description: Maybe you don't want to build a turbine, or maybe you're past that point and now you have cyanite coming out of your ears. You can reprocess it into blutonium and get some more fuel use out of it. The blutonium disintegrates when used up, so this means you can only get two ingots' worth of yellorite out of one starting ingot of fuel. However, the laws of half-life decay conclude that you ultimately get twice the yield per yellorium ingot if you reprocess them!

tasks.longDescription: The reprocessor is pretty boring to make at this point. You can probably guess what some of the ingredients might even be!

It looks like a Big Reactor block, but it's an independent machine. Don't try to stack it into your reactor's frame. You will also need to get water into it. You can try to use buckets of water, but you should also be comfortable with our friend the aqueous accumulator by now. Pipe some water in to whatever side you designate as blue. Feed it two cyanite ingots and it should crank out one blutonium ingot. There's your 2:1 half-life right there.

quests.name: A Turbine Relationship
quests.description: Assuming you built that 5x5x5 reactor with a 3x3x3 inner chamber, and let's assume you have filled it up with some of that liquid ender you got as a reward (drop some on the top layer and let it flow down). That should be pooping out around 1,400 RF/tick, depending on circumstances in the reactor. Good job. Good for you. Do you want... more? Would you like to get more than 4,000 RF/tick? It's turbine time! Warning! This is complicated as all get-go! You need to convert the reactor into a giant steam generator, and then build a large, customizable turbine that is tuned to your reactor.

tasks.longDescription: Right... turbine blocks. This is going to be a 12-block-tall structure that is 5 blocks wide on all sides. You should make room for it near your reactor now! The framing alone is about ... 69 turbine blocks. Then you will need something like 112 to make the glass--and you really do want to have glass on the pretty turbine. Then there's the components. So let's go for a cool 200 turbine blocks. You make a stack of them, and I'll give you the rest.
Now be a good baby and start turning all those turbine blocks into glass. Remember, I'm giving you the extras. Be good!

quests.name: Getting Shafted
quests.description: So what's the turbine doing? It's dissipating the heat from the steam across fan blades spinning along a central shaft. Each blade to dissipite 25mB/tick of steam. You are averaging 700mB/tick of steam. With a single blade per side, that's 28 blades. With 4 blades per shaft level, that's 7 levels. Add on the 3 levels for the coils. Wait, the coils? Yes! Coils are converting the mechanical force of the turbine into RF. Look at the electrum quest! You need to add 3 layers to handle that. So you need 10 shaft pieces. I'll help you out.

tasks.longDescription: You make 5 shaft pieces, and I'll give you 5 more.
Same thing. You make 14 blades, and I'll give you 14 more.

Now here's one people like to forget about. Opposite the side you put the coils--probably the ceiling--you want to put in a shaft bearing. The shaft has to run out from this bearing. It's part of the outer casing.

quests.name: An Electrum Personality
quests.description: So you have a spinny thingy. You need a coil on one end of it to convert the spin into power. There is a lot of voodoo algebra here that cannot be written in this little book. You *could* calculate it. Anyways, many materials work, but I recommend electrum for beginners. You are probably swimming in gold and silver. There are better materials, but you are probably not tooled to handle them (yet). Electrum is in the top five of many options.

tasks.longDescription: Ten?! Yes! Ten! I mean, you actually need TWENTY, but I am a cool dude and will give you the other ten. Electrum is a blend of gold and silver. One each gives you two ingots worth of electrum. If you're using the good old smeltery, then that's, what, 23 gold ores and 23 silver ores. Is that so scary now?

quests.name: A Ludicrous Turbine
quests.description: Ludicrite is the #1 super-duper best coil material that was added to Big Reactors to shut up the overoptimizers that can't help themselves. The mod author regrets it to this day. But whatever, it's there. It is the devil to make! I sprinkled some around in mob drops, but you will need much more if you want to use it in your coils. So look at the recipes, and prove to me you can make one . . . someday.

tasks.longDescription: And by "Crafting task," I mean "actually make it in a crafting table like a Big Baby," not "cheating it in or forcing detection like a Little Baby."

quests.name: You Might Be A Rednet If...
quests.description: Big Reactors has a Rednet port that you can use to control your reactor. Cool kids will set up PID controllers and all kinds of crazy stuff for this, but you can do a very basic differential compensator with two Rednet ports. Set one to output on the white channel to output power capacity %, and the other on its white channel to control rod insertion. The reactor will start to moderate the reaction as your battery fills up, making fuel use very efficient and basically shutting of the reactor when it's not needed.

tasks.longDescription: You need 4 cables per rednet port, and 2 to connect them. So that would be 10 total, but I'm going to get you a rednet port for free, so you only need 6. This quest, however, will trigger if you just give me one because I was hitting a nasty bug where it would only count each group of 8 cables you crafted. :(

By the way, if you start using turbines, you will have to change how this all works. Turbines are slow to get going and have varying efficiencies. At that point, you probably just want to laser drill for constant fuel and leave the thing running 100% at all times.

quests.name: So Hot And Steamy!
quests.description: The Minefactory Reloaded steam boiler takes burnable fuels and turns them into steam. It is a picky beast. It will start at 20C, and pick up heat SLOWLY until it reaches 100C. At that point, it generates steam, so long as you keep feeding it fuel and water. You can feed it fuel from a tree farm, and water from an aquaeous accumulator. There is a demonstration of it in the Minefactory Reloaded tower in Baby's First City.

tasks.longDescription: I should note this is an unconventional way of getting to advanced electrical power. Most people don't do this, but the people that do are awesome. You need some intense materials to do this right!

quests.name: Ender's Conduit
quests.description: We have competing means of delivering RF power--as well as fluids and items. Courtesy of EnderIO, we have these conduits. They have some nice perks. For one, their basic power conduits can deliver more power more cheaply than Thermal Dynamics' conduits. However, the big perk is that these conduits can be stacked together in one block. So you can have a power, item, fluid, and redstone conduit all in the same block. They'll just cram in there. This makes for much more elegant cabling.

tasks.longDescription: The part of all this I screw up is the conduit binder. It's a gravel-intense, but otherwise simple recipe. I just forget about it all the time. You'll need to start with this for your EnderIO conduits. All of them.

Cook the composite into binder. Then you'll need this conductive alloy. You have to combine one redstone dust and one iron ingot in either an induction smelter or an alloy smelter. You pick which one. For one recipe's worth of conduit, you need six binder and three conductive iron.
Make a horizontal strip of binder, a strip of alloys, and another strip of binder, and you will have some conduit!

quests.name: Focusing On Getting Fuel
quests.description: You might whine about how nuclear power isn't "sustainable" like the tree farms are. For what you're doing, and for how much yellorium is in this pack, that doesn't really matter. But hey, maybe sustainability is your thing. If that's the case, use a few lime-colored laser focuses in your laser drill. Or call them "focii" instead of "focuses." English is the devil like that.

tasks.longDescription: I'll trade you 1:1. For best effect, you have to completely load up a laser drill with these. Then you'll get a bunch of uranium and yellorium. You will get them faster than you can burn the stuff. Laser drill? That's a different activity!

quests.name: An Enriching Experience
quests.description: An enrichment chamber is another part of Mekanism's 3x (and higher) ore processing. However, it can also break down some ore blocks more efficiently than other machines like a pulverizer. Look at recipes for ores like nether quartz ore, redstone ore, and diamond ore see which machines do each best. You might need silk touch on a tool to really take advantage of it.

tasks.longDescription: You made it here after making a metallurgic infuser, so you can probably figure this one out. PS: Consider making two of these because you'll eventually need one for a purification chamber.

quests.name: The Trouble With Triples
quests.description: Ore doubling is cool and all, but let's triple the yield now! Mekanism has ways to do that... and more! You could go up to 5x if you do some stuff that is really crazy. However, doing 3x is pretty much just lining up some machines and getting some plumbing working. The main machine you're missing is the purification chamber. However, it needs oxygen, which suddenly drags in other equipment.

tasks.longDescription: You will breathe oxygen into the purifer in order to get your first boost in ore productivity. You can get oxygen be separating oxygen from hydrogen with the electrolytic separators. Note: If you plan to do a lot of this, you probably need a bank of these machines, or at least a some upgrades.
You might have been through this before already, but you need an aqueous accumulator for producing the water the seperator needs. So this is just a detection task.

You'll be getting some hydrogen, and it will build up in the electrolytic separator. You can just have it vent it, but you can also recoup some of your power consumption by pumping it into a gas-burning generator. This isn't power-positive, but it does put a waste product to good use.
You need some pressurized tubes for the hydrogen and oxygen. You may have been given some of this before, but I'm not letting you go unless you craft some this time.
Well, let's poop out the purification chamber too. You will load this up with oxygen, and it will partially convert your ores

quests.name: Taking Control
quests.description: Now you need to make all the little fiddly bits of the turbine. Remember how difficult that was with the original reactor? It should be pretty casual to you now. Building the turbine is going to stink though!

tasks.longDescription: You need *FOUR* fluid ports. That's 2 in and 2 out. That's because we're going to use Mekanism advanced pipes to move the water and steam between the reactor and the turbine. Each one of those can only do 400mB/tick, so you need a pair to cover the flow rate.

So yeah, the reactor needs fluid ports too! Four of them, of course, to much the turbine. Once you put these in, your reactor becomes "actively-cooled." It will stop generating RF and will instead generate steam. Lots of steam. If you followed the specifications, you'll get a range of 749mB/tick to 680mB/tick. If you altered the design, then this whole scheme falls apart and you're on your own! :p

quests.name: Taking It To The Bank
quests.description: Ender IO capacitor banks are very versatile. They serve as portable batterys, permanent RF-storing stations, and machines for charging portable electronics. If you shift-right-click one with a wrench, it will break while keeping its charge. If you right-click it normally, you can configure which sides do what, what rate it charges/discharges, and pop stuff into charge.

tasks.longDescription: It is nice to have some kind of power storage nearby your main power line. At a glance, you can look at it and see if you have problems. If it's full, your power generators are keeping up. If it's draining, then you have a problem! Keep a second one charged and off the grid as a backup grid to restore things if you have a total outage,

quests.name: A Stirling Proposition
quests.description: A stirling generator is a basic solid-fuel power generation machine. It will live off of basic fuels like coal and wood, burning them at 20 RF/tick. A survivalist generator is more efficient, but requires much more metal and only produces a puny 5 RF/tick.

tasks.longDescription: Your quest reward is an upgrade that increases the generator's performance. It'll make it pretty darn competitive!

quests.name: Your First Noisy Mek Machine
quests.description: Just about every machine in Mekanism starts with alloys produced in the metallurgic infuser. The basic alloy takes one redstone dust and crams it into an ingot of iron. Circuit boards are created by cramming redstone dust into osmium ingots. There are more advanced products made from the infuser too. Side note: This quest repeats some post-scarcity quests for the digital miner. Double the fun! Double the rewards! Oh, heh, you can also use it to make steel. Hint hint.

tasks.longDescription: This is just a detection task--not a crafting task. This quest is repeated with the digital miner because it also needs it. Surprise, surprise, it's a Mekanism machine too!
Feed one redstone dust and one ingot into your infuser, and it will whir away. Literally. It makes crazy noises.
